Looks nervously at Pete, unsure of what will happen next.
Races inside the house shouting at Rosalyn, confronts her about her boyfriend and nail polish, showing emotional distress.
Smells the nail polish found in another man's car, indicating suspicion and jealousy.
Denies accusations about working for the government, showing loyalty to Carmine.

Races inside shouting and confronts Rosalyn aggressively, indicating emotional impulsiveness that may undermine his effectiveness.
Is caught off guard and kidnapped with a canvas bag over his head, suggesting a failure to anticipate danger or protect himself.
Ushers Danny out of the room to protect him from danger.
Screams at Rosalyn in front of Danny, causing distress.
Expresses concern about the danger Rosalyn's boyfriend poses to the family.
Recognizes the immediate danger and tries to protect his son by ushering him out of the room.
Screams at Rosalyn and escalates the emotional tension, potentially worsening the situation.
Throws Rosalyn's clothes back into the closet, insists she is not going to Miami, and tells her to shut her mouth.
Expresses concern about danger and tries to keep things 'normal' despite Rosalyn's wishes.
Almost falls and is helped up by Rosalyn, showing vulnerability and physical weakness.
Firmly insists Rosalyn is not going to Miami because it is too dangerous, showing awareness of risk and control over the situation.
Throws Rosalyn's clothes back into the closet, physically enforcing his decision and maintaining order.
Struggles physically, drops heart pills, almost falls, and is out of breath, indicating physical weakness or stress impacting his capability.
Claims to have a plan despite being visibly unwell and under pressure, showing confidence and mental focus.
Reassures Rosalyn he can take care of her and Danny, promising to save them and keep money safe.
Dismisses a damaging rumor about his wife firmly and protectively.
Laughs along with others after being threatened and humiliated.
Comes up with a plan under extreme pressure (being choked with a bag on his head).
Confidently promises two million wired in this week despite skepticism from others.
Reassures his wife and tries to maintain control of the situation despite personal and external chaos.
Responds gently and appreciatively to Rosalyn's plan despite incredulity.
Encourages Rosalyn to be quiet and avoid discussing conspiracies with Pete.
Forces himself to respond gently and appreciatively to Rosalyn's unsolicited plan, showing social tact and control.
Engages Rosalyn in discussing the plan and attempts to clarify next steps, demonstrating willingness to collaborate and lead.
Allows Rosalyn to dominate the conversation and dictate the plan, showing some passivity and lack of assertiveness.
Admits Rosalyn was right and compliments her sincerely ('You're so smart. Good job, peaches.')
Accepts the idea of divorce calmly without argument or bitterness
Holds his head and struggles to hold it together during a difficult conversation
Acknowledges Rosalyn was right and accepts the need to face facts about their relationship and divorce calmly.
Holds his head and struggles emotionally but maintains composure during a difficult conversation.
Responds with short, resigned affirmations ('OK', 'Alright') showing acceptance but limited assertiveness.
Maintains composure and eye contact during tense frisking and security checks, indicating confidence and awareness.
Enters a high-risk meeting with a mob lawyer, showing calculated risk-taking and understanding of criminal protocols.
Does not speak in the tense elevator moment, possibly indicating cautiousness and strategic silence.
Refuses to make a large payment without the proper authority present, stating 'We can't make that decision. It's not the right thing. It's not the right time.'
Refuses to make a large financial decision without the proper authority present, showing caution and awareness of appropriate procedure.
Apologizes to Simone for the way business is being handled.
Insists on following the plan and rejects Edith's suggestion to call the Sheik, showing inflexibility.
Politely but firmly tells Edith that the decision is not hers to make.
Attempts to assert control over a situation and advises caution, showing awareness of proper business conduct.
Is overridden by others (Edith and Richie) and fails to maintain authority, indicating a lack of influence or control in the moment.
Looks preoccupied during a successful money transfer and deal closing.
Admits to Carmine Polito that the sheik does not exist and wants to be real and honest with him despite the difficult situation.
Looks distressed and appears emotionally affected by having to confront Carmine with the truth about the Feds.

Expresses desire to make things right and is visibly upset, even in tears.
Admits to being forced into actions due to external pressure (Syd in jail).
Offers help and support to Carmine despite conflict and violence.
Removes glasses and stares at Carmine, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Admits being forced into a bad situation and shows emotional vulnerability by being in tears and upset.
Attempts to de-escalate conflict and offers a plan to help Carmine out, showing some problem-solving and negotiation skills.
Appears unable to prevent Carmine's anger and physical violence, indicating a lack of control over the situation.

Fails to anticipate or prevent the violent reaction from Carmine, resulting in physical harm and emotional damage.
Despite being beaten and emotionally shaken, attempts to make amends and shows remorse.

Maintains composure and calmly answers questions about missing money despite tension.

Claims ignorance about the missing money despite the anonymous tip, showing a lack of knowledge about a critical issue.

Appears unsure or unable to provide a clear explanation or solution to the missing money problem.
Tries to reason calmly with Richie Dimaso, pointing out the potential negative consequences of incompetence in the investigation.
Points out the risk of appearing incompetent to Richie Dimaso, demonstrating awareness of optics and legal strategy.
Remains calm and rational in a tense situation, showing confidence and control.
Calmly challenges Richie Dimaso's accusations and points out the irony and unfairness in targeting small-time operators instead of bigger criminals.
Uses sarcasm and a somewhat defensive tone when confronted, focusing on self-preservation rather than empathy.
Calmly challenges Richie Dimaso's narrative by pointing out the irony and flaws in his story, showing quick thinking and verbal skill.
Uses persuasive language to undermine Richie’s position and make him doubt his own story, demonstrating confidence and strategic communication.
Avoids direct confrontation or admission of guilt, instead deflecting and reframing the situation to his advantage.

Reflects on successfully taking down major corrupt figures through the FBI sting operation.
Acknowledges the complexity and moral ambiguity of the targets, showing insight into the situation.

Mentions moving in with Sydney and picking up Danny from school, indicating family involvement.

Feels haunted by the loss of Carmine's friendship despite the legal outcome.

Assures Pete that he never let his boss take a loss, protecting him from trouble.
Nods silently as Rosalyn gives him her nail finish and says goodbye.
Walks hand in hand with Sydney and Danny, showing connection and care.
Insists that his boss never took a nickel and can't be implicated, showing awareness of legal risks and loyalty.
Decides to leave the conning life behind and reinvents himself legitimately by obtaining a bank loan and opening an art gallery.
